<!--Pakistan, speaking on behalf of 77 developing countries plus China, put the onus on industrial countries to increase funding and technology help.

Though the world faces a common goal, countries must meet them according to their "respective capabilities," Pakistani delegate Jamil Ahmad said. That meant deep emissions cuts by the developed world and helping less capable countries build their capacity to adapt to new weather conditions.

The industrial world must "move significantly beyond the current institutional and financial arrangements," Ahmad said.

It is the first time government climate delegations are meeting since the U.N.-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change issued a series of reports this year drawing on the studies of some 2,500 scientists.

The reports warned that climate changes will hit poor countries hardest — less rain in arid areas like northern Africa and more severe floods in river deltas like Bangladesh. Millions of poor people will also suffer from greater hunger, thirst and disease, and as much as 30 percent of species will be threatened with extinction.
